messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> wrote:
>
> >So said tcxu on 2003-06-13 --------------------
> >Are we allowed to insert temporary lines of code (public methods) >
> >in the classes tested to obtain private information/methods?
> >Otherwise we can only use Junitx to have access to private members.
>
> Sure... who's going to stop you?

Strickly speaking, that's true... the TDD-police won't show up at your
door....

but... I see two things:

1) adding a way to obtain/test private information.

Sure... if you really need to. My view is generally that if
something's private then it isn't part of the external behaviour of
the code... and so shouldn't be the subject of a test... that would be
testing the implementation of the behaviour.. and not the behaviour
itself.

As a rule, I don't test private methods directly. Private methods are
an implementation detail, and (the way I work) the result of
refactoring. If they become important or useful enough that they are
promoted to public, then they need direct tests... but not until then.

However, it can be a useful approach to writing characterization tests
for an existing codebase.

2) "insert temporary lines of code"

No. Not temporary. If you add code in support of a test it has to
have the life span of the test, and tests are meant to be long lived.
You don't write a test to make sure things work then throw the test
away. The test is like an alter-ego of the code. Like that episode
of Star Trek where Kirk gets ripped in two by the transporter. Either
in isolation doesn't make sense.

Dave
